facts.mainTitle: Important Facts About the Country of Moldova

sections.title: Moldova Introduction
content: Moldova is a landlocked country in Eastern Europe, bordered by Romania and Ukraine. The service sector has grown to dominate Moldova's economy and accounts for over 60% of the nation's GDP. While the country is landlocked, it is close to the Black Sea, (separated from an estuary of the Black Sea by only 3 km of Ukrainian territory).

sections.title: What to Know about Moldova's Geography
content: Moldova is a landlocked nation in the northeastern part of the Balkan region in Europe. The capital, Chișinău, is located in the south-central region. The country shares borders with Ukraine to the north, east and south, while Romania lies to the west. The majority of Moldova is situated between the Prut and Dniester rivers, which wind through the region.

sections.title: Climate in Moldova
content: Moldova experiences a warm and moderately continental climate, characterized by a prolonged frost-free period, relatively mild winters, notable temperature fluctuations and extended droughts in the southern regions. The average annual temperature ranges from the mid-40s °F (about 8 °C) in the north to the low 50s °F (about 10 °C) in the south.

sections.title: The Culture of Moldova
content: Moldova, predominantly an Eastern Orthodox country, observes Christian holidays. Different ethnic groups within Moldova adhere to their own customs and culinary traditions. Independence Day on August 27 commemorates Moldova's separation from the Soviet Union.

sections.title: Languages Spoken in Moldova
content: The constitution designates Romanian as the official language of the country. Around the mid-2000s, it became widely accepted that Moldovan and Romanian were essentially identical languages.

faqs.question: Salary Payment
faqs.answer: Salaries in Moldova are typically paid in Moldovan Leu (MDL), the national currency. Payment is made through bank transfer to the employee's account, usually on a monthly basis. The employment contract may specify alternative payment arrangements if mutually agreed upon by employer and employee.

faqs.question: Timesheets & Record Keeping
faqs.answer: Employers must maintain accurate records of working hours, overtime, night work, and leave. Employees are required to submit timesheets according to company policy. All employment documentation must be kept for inspection by the State Labor Inspectorate for the period specified by law.

faqs.question: Annual Leave
faqs.answer: Employees in Moldova are entitled to a minimum of 28 calendar days of paid annual leave per year. Additional leave may be granted based on working conditions, collective agreements, or employment contracts. Annual leave must be coordinated with the employer and scheduled in advance.

faqs.question: Maternity & Parental Leave
faqs.answer: Female employees are entitled to 126 calendar days of maternity leave, with 70 days before and 56 days after birth. Extended parental leave is also available until the child reaches 3 years of age. Maternity and parental benefits are provided through the state social insurance system.

faqs.question: Paternity Leave
faqs.answer: Fathers are entitled to 14 calendar days of paid paternity leave following the birth of a child. This leave can be taken during the first 56 days after birth. Paternity leave supports fathers in participating actively in early childcare and family responsibilities.

faqs.question: Adoption Leave
faqs.answer: Adoptive parents are entitled to leave similar to biological parents to support the adoption process and child integration. The duration and benefits depend on the child's age and circumstances. Both adoptive mothers and fathers may be eligible for adoption leave under Moldovan labor legislation.

sections.title: Armenia Introduction
content: Armenia is a landlocked country in the South Caucasus region of Eurasia, bordered by Turkey, Georgia, Azerbaijan, and Iran. Known for its ancient history, rich cultural heritage, and growing tech sector, Armenia has become an attractive destination for international business.

sections.title: What to Know about Armenia's Geography
content: Armenia is located in the highlands surrounding Mount Ararat. The capital, Yerevan, is one of the world's oldest continuously inhabited cities. The country features mountainous terrain with the Lesser Caucasus mountain range covering much of the territory.

sections.title: Languages Spoken in Armenia
content: Armenian is the official language. Russian is widely spoken, and English is increasingly common in business and among younger generations.

faqs.question: Salary Payment
faqs.answer: Salaries in Armenia are paid in Armenian Dram (AMD), the national currency. Payment is typically made through bank transfer to the employee's designated account on a monthly basis. Employers and employees may agree on alternative payment arrangements as specified in the employment contract.

faqs.question: Timesheets & Record Keeping
faqs.answer: Employers are required to maintain accurate records of working hours, including overtime and leave. Employees must submit timesheets as required by company procedures and labor regulations. Employment records must be kept available for inspection by the State Labor Inspectorate.

faqs.question: Annual Leave
faqs.answer: Employees in Armenia are entitled to a minimum of 20 working days of paid annual leave per year. Additional leave days may be provided based on employment contracts, working conditions, or collective agreements. Leave scheduling must be coordinated between the employer and employee.

faqs.question: Maternity & Parental Leave
faqs.answer: Female employees are entitled to 140 calendar days of maternity leave, with 70 days before and 70 days after birth. In case of complicated birth or multiple children, extended leave is provided. Maternity benefits are covered through the social insurance system to support mothers during this period.

faqs.question: Paternity Leave
faqs.answer: Fathers in Armenia are entitled to paternity leave following the birth of a child. The duration and terms are regulated by labor legislation. Paternity leave enables fathers to support their families and participate in early childcare responsibilities.

faqs.question: Adoption Leave
faqs.answer: Adoptive parents are entitled to leave provisions similar to biological parents to facilitate child integration into the family. The specific terms and duration are outlined in Armenian labor law. Both adoptive mothers and fathers may qualify for adoption leave benefits.

sections.title: Georgia Introduction
content: Georgia is a country at the intersection of Europe and Asia, bordered by Russia, Turkey, Armenia, and Azerbaijan. Known for its diverse landscapes, ancient winemaking traditions, and business-friendly environment, Georgia has become an emerging hub for startups and international companies.

sections.title: What to Know about Georgia's Geography
content: Georgia is located in the Caucasus region, with the Black Sea to the west. The capital, Tbilisi, is situated in the eastern part of the country. Georgia features varied geography including the Greater Caucasus mountains in the north and the Lesser Caucasus in the south.

sections.title: Languages Spoken in Georgia
content: Georgian is the official language. Russian and English are commonly spoken, especially in business environments and tourism sectors.

faqs.question: Salary Payment
faqs.answer: Salaries in Georgia are paid in Georgian Lari (GEL), the national currency. Payment is typically made through bank transfer to the employee's account on a monthly basis. Employers may agree with employees on alternative payment arrangements or foreign currency payment if specified in the employment contract.

faqs.question: Timesheets & Record Keeping
faqs.answer: Employers must maintain records of working hours, overtime, and leave as required by Georgian labor law. Employees should submit accurate timesheets according to company policy. Proper record-keeping ensures compliance with labor regulations and protects both employer and employee rights.

faqs.question: Annual Leave
faqs.answer: Employees in Georgia are entitled to a minimum of 24 working days of paid annual leave per year. Additional leave may be provided based on employment contracts or company policies. Annual leave must be scheduled in coordination with the employer to ensure operational continuity.

faqs.question: Maternity & Parental Leave
faqs.answer: Female employees are entitled to 730 calendar days (approximately 2 years) of maternity and childcare leave, with 183 days before and after birth covered by state maternity benefits. The remaining period is unpaid but job-protected. This comprehensive leave policy supports mothers in balancing work and family responsibilities.

faqs.question: Paternity Leave
faqs.answer: Georgian labor law provides for paternity leave, though specific provisions may vary. Fathers are encouraged to take leave to support their families following the birth of a child. The terms and duration should be coordinated with the employer according to company policy and legal requirements.

faqs.question: Adoption Leave
faqs.answer: Adoptive parents are entitled to leave provisions to support the adoption process and facilitate child integration into the family. The specific terms are outlined in Georgian labor legislation. Both adoptive mothers and fathers may be eligible for adoption leave benefits similar to biological parents.
